name: Institute for Understanding Anti-Palestinian Racism
theoryOfChange: The Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism (IUAPR) bases its work on the 'Anti-Palestinian Racism: Naming, Framing and Manifestations' report by the Arab Canadian Lawyers Association (ACLA). This report serves as a framework that provides a description of anti-Palestinian racism, explains how it operates to silence discourse on Palestine, and outlines its impacts on individuals and the broader community. It is used as a working description and framework for institutions, organizations, companies, and individuals to address incidents of anti-Palestinian racism. The framework details various forms of anti-Palestinian racism, including denying the Nakba, justifying violence against Palestinians, failing to acknowledge Palestinians as an Indigenous people, erasing their human rights, excluding Palestinian perspectives, and defaming Palestinians and their allies.

evaluationSources: UNCORROBORATED: UCSF Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval for research

zakatClaimEvidence: The official website and donation pages of the Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism (IUAPR) do not explicitly mention 'zakat' or 'zakat donations', nor do they indicate dedicated zakat funds or campaigns. The organization is a U.S. 501(c)(3) tax-exempt non-profit organization focused on research, education, and advocacy to end anti-Palestinian racism. (Source: https://antipalestinianracism.org/donate)

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 16/50, the charity addresses an urgent advocacy cause but shows low specific fit for traditional Muslim donor expectations due to a lack of detailed track record [1]. Contributions are categorized as sadaqah-eligible for those interested in general charitable giving toward social justice [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization's impact score of 18/50 reflects its focus on capacity building through education and research [1]. However, effectiveness is difficult to measure as specific beneficiary costs and program outcomes are not publicly disclosed in financial filings [3].

Donors can support these initiatives through various digital giving methods hosted on their official platform [2].

strengths_deep_dive: The Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism Inc distinguishes itself through a highly specialized mission focused on <cite id="2">research, education, and reporting</cite>. By concentrating on systemic advocacy within the <cite id="3">USA</cite>, the organization aims to build capacity and provide educational training programs for public awareness. Their published materials track specific advocacy outcomes, such as documenting instances where <cite id="4">40 faculty associations rejected the IHRA definition</cite>, demonstrating engagement with academic and institutional policy discussions.
rich_narrative.summary: The Institute for the Understanding of Anti-Palestinian Racism Inc is a specialized nonprofit dedicated to systemic research and advocacy regarding discrimination. Operating primarily in the <cite id="3">USA</cite>, the organization focuses on <cite id="2">research, education, and reporting</cite> to address specific forms of prejudice. As an emerging organization, it provides platforms for <cite id="2">public education and training</cite> to raise awareness about systemic issues. The organization's impact tracking notes that its resources have been utilized in contexts where <cite id="4">40 faculty associations rejected the IHRA definition</cite>. Donors can support these initiatives through <cite id="2">digital giving methods</cite> hosted on their official platform. However, the organization currently exhibits <cite id="1">limited public financial transparency</cite>, with missing data regarding its program expense ratio and working capital. Furthermore, governance data indicates a <cite id="1">board size of only 2 members</cite>, which presents a structural limitation for organizational oversight. Due to these factors, the charity has a <cite id="3">low data confidence score</cite> and is not currently fully rated by major charity evaluators.
